title: Diabetic Nephropathy with Nephrotic Syndrome
source: ISN India Guidelines - Diabetic Kidney Disease
chief_complaint: Progressive swelling of face and legs for 3 months
presentation: A 52-year-old businessman with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes for 18 years presents with progressive facial puffiness, bilateral pedal edema, and frothy urine for 3 months. His HbA1c has been consistently above 9%. He also has hypertension and diabetic retinopathy.
history: T2DM for 18 years, on glimepiride and metformin. HbA1c 9.5% consistently. Hypertension for 10 years on amlodipine. Progressive swelling: face in mornings, legs by evening. Frothy urine noticed for 4 months. Reduced urine output. No hematuria. Known bilateral proliferative diabetic retinopathy (laser done). Peripheral neuropathy (burning feet). No NSAID use.
physical_exam: Periorbital edema, bilateral pitting pedal edema up to knees. BP 165/100. Fundoscopy: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy with laser scars. Reduced sensation in stocking distribution (neuropathy). No rash. No joint swelling. Abdomen: Mild ascites.
investigations: Urine: Protein 4+, 24-hour urine protein 5.2g (nephrotic range >3.5g). Urine albumin-creatinine ratio (UACR): 3500 mg/g (severely increased). Serum albumin: 2.0 g/dL. Cholesterol: 320 mg/dL (dyslipidemia). Creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL, eGFR: 22 mL/min (CKD Stage 4). HbA1c: 9.8%. Renal USG: Bilateral normal-sized kidneys (unlike other causes of CKD), increased cortical echogenicity. ANA, C3/C4, ANCA: Normal. Hepatitis B/C: Negative. Renal biopsy (if done): Nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules).
diagnosis: Diabetic nephropathy (diabetic kidney disease) with nephrotic syndrome — CKD Stage 4
learning_points: Diabetic nephropathy is the leading cause of ESRD in India and globally
Biopsy not always needed if: longstanding DM + retinopathy + gradual proteinuria increase + normal-sized kidneys
ACEi/ARB is mandatory for proteinuria reduction (target <500 mg/day or 50% reduction)
SGLT2 inhibitors (dapagliflozin/empagliflozin) reduce CKD progression independent of diabetes control
Finerenone (non-steroidal MRA) is a new addition to DKD management
Prepare for dialysis when eGFR <15, start AV fistula creation at eGFR <20
india_context: India has 77 million diabetics (2nd highest globally). Diabetic nephropathy accounts for 30-40% of patients on dialysis in India. Only 10% of ESRD patients in India can access dialysis due to cost. PM-National Dialysis Programme provides free dialysis at district hospitals.

title: Nephrotic Syndrome in a Child — Minimal Change Disease
chief_complaint: Puffy eyes and swollen legs for 1 week
presentation: A 5-year-old boy is brought by his mother with progressive puffy eyes noticed every morning for 1 week, now progressing to bilateral leg swelling and abdominal distension. The mother reports his urine has become frothy and reduced in amount. He had an upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago.
history: Upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago. Periorbital puffiness noticed 1 week ago, initially mornings only, now persistent. Progressive bilateral leg swelling. Abdominal distension. Frothy urine, reduced volume. No gross hematuria. No fever. No rash. No joint pains. Previously healthy child. Vaccinations up to date. No family history of kidney disease.
physical_exam: Periorbital edema, bilateral pitting pedal edema. Distended abdomen with shifting dullness (ascites). Scrotal edema. No rash. No hepatosplenomegaly. BP normal for age. No hypertension. Rest of examination normal.
investigations: Urine: Protein 4+, no RBCs, no casts. Spot UPCR: 8.5 (nephrotic range >2 in children). 24-hour urine protein: 3.5g/m²/day (or UPCR >2). Serum albumin: 1.5 g/dL. Cholesterol: 380 mg/dL. Triglycerides: 280. Creatinine: 0.4 (normal for age). C3, C4: Normal. ANA: Negative. HBsAg: Negative. ASO: Mildly elevated (recent URTI). Renal USG: Normal-sized kidneys, no structural abnormality.
diagnosis: Idiopathic nephrotic syndrome — most likely minimal change disease (first episode, steroid trial indicated)
learning_points: In children 1-10 years, nephrotic syndrome is MCD until proven otherwise — no biopsy needed for first episode
Biopsy indications in children: Age <1 or >10, steroid resistance, frequent relapses, atypical features (hematuria, low C3, HTN)
Steroid protocol: Prednisolone 2mg/kg/day (max 60mg) for 6 weeks, then 1.5mg/kg alternate day for 6 weeks (modified ISKDC)
90-95% of MCD responds to steroids within 4 weeks (steroid-sensitive)
Frequent relapsers: Consider levamisole, cyclophosphamide, MMF, or rituximab
Complications: Peritonitis (pneumococcal), thrombosis, infections — give pneumococcal vaccine
india_context: Childhood nephrotic syndrome incidence in India is 12-16 per 100,000 children (2x Western rates). The Indian Society of Pediatric Nephrology (ISPN) recommends modified ISKDC protocol. Generic prednisolone is affordable. Steroid-resistant cases require biopsy and second-line agents. Rituximab access is improving through charitable trusts.

title: IgA Nephropathy with Recurrent Gross Hematuria
chief_complaint: Recurrent episodes of red-colored urine coinciding with sore throats
presentation: A 24-year-old college student presents with his third episode of painless gross hematuria (cola-colored urine) that started 24 hours after developing a sore throat. Previous episodes resolved spontaneously. He is now found to have persistent microscopic hematuria and proteinuria between episodes.
history: Third episode of gross hematuria in 2 years. Each episode coincides with upper respiratory infection (synpharyngitic — within 24-48 hours, NOT 2-3 weeks like PSGN). Cola-colored urine, no clots. Resolves in 3-5 days. Between episodes: routine check found microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria. Current: sore throat yesterday, today noticed dark urine. Mild loin discomfort bilateral. No dysuria. No edema. No family history of kidney disease. No hearing issues.
physical_exam: BP 145/92 (mild hypertension for age). No edema. No rash. No joint swelling. Throat: Mildly congested. No hepatosplenomegaly. Examination otherwise normal.
investigations: Urine: RBCs 3+, dysmorphic RBCs on phase contrast (glomerular), RBC casts, Protein 1+. UPCR: 1.2 g/g. Serum creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL. Serum IgA: 450 mg/dL (elevated). C3, C4: Normal (KEY — distinguishes from PSGN where C3 is low). ASO: Mildly elevated (concurrent URTI). ANA, ANCA: Negative. Renal biopsy: Mesangial proliferative GN, IgA dominant immunofluorescence deposits. Oxford classification: M1 E1 S0 T0 C1.
diagnosis: IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) with recurrent synpharyngitic gross hematuria
learning_points: IgA nephropathy is the commonest GN worldwide and in India
Synpharyngitic hematuria (within 24-48h of URTI) vs PSGN (2-3 weeks after URTI) — KEY differentiator
Normal C3 in IgA nephropathy vs LOW C3 in PSGN
Oxford MEST-C classification guides prognosis and treatment
Treatment: ACEi/ARB for proteinuria >0.5g/day; steroids if proteinuria >1g despite RAAS blockade
30-40% progress to ESRD over 20 years — not as benign as previously thought
india_context: IgA nephropathy accounts for 20-30% of renal biopsies in India. Northeast India (Assam, Meghalaya) reports higher prevalence. Indian Renal Biopsy Registry data shows IgAN as the most common primary GN. KDIGO 2021 guidelines incorporated into Indian nephrology practice.

title: Acute Kidney Injury — Contrast-Induced Nephropathy
chief_complaint: Reduced urine output after coronary angiography
presentation: A 65-year-old man with diabetes and CKD Stage 3 (baseline creatinine 1.8) develops oliguria 48 hours after coronary angiography with contrast dye. He had an elective angiogram for stable angina. He was not adequately hydrated pre-procedure and his metformin was not stopped.
history: Elective coronary angiography 48 hours ago for stable angina. 150 mL iodinated contrast used. Known CKD Stage 3 (creatinine 1.8, eGFR 38). T2DM on metformin, glimepiride. Hypertension. No pre-hydration given. Metformin not stopped before procedure. Urine output dropped to 200 mL in last 24 hours. No fever. No hypotension during procedure.
physical_exam: Mild bilateral pedal edema. BP 140/80. JVP mildly elevated. Lungs: Bibasal crepitations. Femoral access site: Clean, no hematoma. Otherwise unremarkable.
investigations: Creatinine: 4.2 (from baseline 1.8 — >2x increase). BUN: 65. Potassium: 5.8. Bicarbonate: 16 (metabolic acidosis). Urine output: 200 mL/24h (oliguric AKI). Urine: FENa 0.8% (prerenal pattern initially), muddy brown casts (ATN developing). Urine eosinophils: Negative. Lactate: 2.5. Renal USG: Normal-sized kidneys, no hydronephrosis. CBC: Normal. ECG: Peaked T waves (hyperkalemia).
diagnosis: Contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CI-AKI) superimposed on CKD Stage 3, with hyperkalemia
learning_points: CI-AKI defined: Creatinine rise >0.5 mg/dL or >25% from baseline within 48-72 hours of contrast
Risk factors: Pre-existing CKD (most important), diabetes, dehydration, high contrast volume, nephrotoxic drugs
Prevention: IV normal saline hydration (1 mL/kg/hr for 12h pre and post), use low-osmolar contrast, minimize volume
Metformin must be stopped 48h before contrast in CKD (risk of lactic acidosis if AKI develops)
NAC (N-acetylcysteine) — no longer recommended (no proven benefit per PRESERVE trial)
Hyperkalemia emergency: IV calcium gluconate (membrane stabilizer) + insulin-dextrose + salbutamol nebulization
india_context: With increasing cardiac catheterization in India (>500,000/year), CI-AKI is a growing problem. Many patients have undiagnosed CKD at the time of angiography. Pre-hydration protocols are often skipped due to high patient volume. ISN India recommends mandatory eGFR check before all contrast procedures.

title: Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis — ANCA Vasculitis
chief_complaint: Rapidly worsening kidney function with bloody urine and cough
presentation: A 55-year-old woman presents with 3 weeks of gross hematuria, progressive oliguria, malaise, and hemoptysis. Her creatinine has risen from normal to 6.5 mg/dL in just 3 weeks. She also has nasal crusting and recurrent sinusitis for 6 months. She has coughed up blood twice.
history: Gross hematuria for 3 weeks, cola-colored. Reduced urine output progressively. Malaise, fatigue, weight loss 4 kg over 2 months. Nasal stuffiness and bloody crusting for 6 months (ENT treated as chronic sinusitis). Hemoptysis x 2 episodes (pulmonary involvement). Joint pains (wrists, knees). No rash. No hearing loss. Previously healthy, no prior kidney disease. Creatinine 3 months ago: 0.9 mg/dL.
physical_exam: Pale, edematous. BP 160/95. Nasal mucosa: Crusted, granular (saddle nose deformity developing). Lungs: Bilateral crepitations (pulmonary hemorrhage). Skin: No purpura. Joints: Mild synovitis wrists. Urine: Visibly bloody.
investigations: Creatinine: 6.5 (was 0.9 three months ago — RPGN). Urine: RBCs 3+, RBC casts (active GN), Protein 2+. c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA): Strongly positive. p-ANCA: Negative. Anti-GBM: Negative. ANA: Negative. C3/C4: Normal. CXR: Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates (hemorrhage). CT chest: Ground-glass opacities (diffuse alveolar hemorrhage). Renal biopsy: Crescentic GN (>50% crescents), pauci-immune pattern on IF. ENT biopsy: Granulomatous inflammation.
diagnosis: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's) — ANCA-associated vasculitis with RPGN and pulmonary hemorrhage
learning_points: RPGN = doubling of creatinine in days to weeks — nephrological emergency requiring urgent biopsy
Three types of crescentic GN: Type I (anti-GBM, linear IF), Type II (immune complex, granular IF), Type III (pauci-immune, ANCA-associated)
GPA triad: Upper airway (sinusitis, saddle nose) + Lower airway (hemorrhage) + Kidney (crescentic GN)
c-ANCA/PR3 = GPA; p-ANCA/MPO = MPA (microscopic polyangiitis)
Treatment: Pulse methylprednisolone + cyclophosphamide (or rituximab) induction, then azathioprine maintenance
Plasmapheresis for pulmonary hemorrhage or dialysis-requiring RPGN (PEXIVAS trial)
india_context: ANCA vasculitis is increasingly recognized in India. Indian Renal Biopsy Registry shows crescentic GN accounts for 10-15% of biopsies. Many cases are diagnosed late due to initial treatment as 'sinusitis'. Cyclophosphamide is available and affordable. Rituximab access is improving. Dialysis may be needed as bridge during induction.

title: Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis in a Child
chief_complaint: Puffy face, dark urine, and reduced urination after skin infection
presentation: An 8-year-old boy from a low-income family in Patna presents with sudden onset facial puffiness, cola-colored urine, and reduced urine output for 3 days. He had multiple infected insect bites (impetigo) on his legs 3 weeks ago that were treated with topical ointment only.
history: Multiple infected insect bites on both legs 3 weeks ago, crusted lesions (impetigo). Treated with topical mupirocin. 3 weeks later: sudden facial puffiness, cola-colored urine, reduced volume. Headache. No sore throat. No fever currently. No rash. No joint pains. Lives in crowded conditions, poor sanitation. Similar illness in a neighborhood child last month.
physical_exam: Periorbital edema, mild bilateral pedal edema. BP 140/95 (hypertensive for age). Healing impetigo lesions on both legs (crusted, resolving). No rash. No joint swelling. Abdomen: No ascites (unlike nephrotic syndrome). Fundoscopy: Normal (no hypertensive changes yet).
investigations: Urine: RBCs 3+ (dysmorphic), RBC casts, Protein 1-2+. Creatinine: 1.2 (elevated for age). C3: 25 mg/dL (markedly LOW — key finding). C4: Normal. ASO titer: 800 IU/mL (elevated). Anti-DNase B: Positive (more sensitive for post-skin infection PSGN). Throat swab: Negative (not pharyngitis-associated in this case). CBC: Hb 10.5 (dilutional anemia). Renal USG: Normal-sized kidneys, mildly echogenic.
diagnosis: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) following skin infection (impetigo)
learning_points: PSGN: Nephritic presentation 2-3 weeks after pharyngitis OR 3-6 weeks after skin infection
Low C3 with normal C4 (alternative pathway activation) is the hallmark — differentiates from IgA nephropathy (normal C3)
Self-limiting in children: >95% recover completely. C3 normalizes in 6-8 weeks
Treatment is supportive: Salt/fluid restriction, antihypertensives (furosemide, nifedipine), no immunosuppression needed
Biopsy indications: Persistent low C3 >8 weeks, worsening renal function, nephrotic-range proteinuria
Anti-DNase B is more sensitive than ASO for skin-infection-associated PSGN
india_context: PSGN remains common in India, especially in children from lower socioeconomic groups. Impetigo during monsoon/hot months is a major trigger. Group A strep prevalence is high in overcrowded settings. ICMR data shows declining incidence with improved hygiene but still significant in rural areas.

title: Renal Tubular Acidosis Type 1 with Nephrolithiasis
chief_complaint: Recurrent kidney stones and muscle weakness
presentation: A 30-year-old Rajasthani woman presents with her fourth episode of kidney stones in 3 years, now with bilateral flank pain and muscle weakness. She has been found to have persistent hypokalemia despite supplementation. She also reports polyuria and polydipsia. Stone analysis from a previous episode showed calcium phosphate.
history: Four episodes of renal colic in 3 years. Previous stone analysis: Calcium phosphate (not calcium oxalate). Persistent muscle weakness and fatigue. Polyuria (3-4 liters/day), polydipsia. Muscle cramps, especially at night. Hypokalemia found on multiple occasions (K+ 2.5-3.0 despite supplements). No diarrhea. No laxative use. No family history of stones or kidney disease. Dry climate (Rajasthan).
physical_exam: Thin build. Mild proximal muscle weakness (difficulty rising from chair). Hyporeflexia. Bilateral renal angle tenderness. No bony deformities. No dental enamel defects. Rest examination normal.
investigations: ABG: pH 7.28, HCO3 14 (normal anion gap metabolic acidosis — NAGMA). Anion gap: 10 (normal). K+: 2.4 (hypokalemia). Urine pH: 6.8 (inappropriately alkaline despite systemic acidosis — KEY). Urine anion gap: +15 (positive — impaired ammonium excretion). Creatinine: 1.5. Calcium: 9.0. Phosphate: 3.5. PTH: Normal. 24-hour urine calcium: Elevated (hypercalciuria). CT KUB: Bilateral medullary nephrocalcinosis, right ureteric calculus 8mm. Bone density: Osteopenia (calcium mobilized from bones to buffer acidosis).
diagnosis: Distal (Type 1) renal tubular acidosis with recurrent calcium phosphate nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis
learning_points: Distal RTA: Inability to acidify urine below pH 5.3 despite systemic acidosis
Clue: Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis + urine pH >5.5 + positive urine anion gap
Calcium phosphate stones (not oxalate) + nephrocalcinosis = think dRTA
Hypokalemia in dRTA (unlike Type 4 RTA which has hyperkalemia)
Treatment: Oral potassium citrate (alkalinization + potassium replacement + citrate inhibits stone formation)
Screen for Sjögren syndrome and autoimmune conditions in adult-onset dRTA
india_context: Rajasthan has the highest nephrolithiasis prevalence in India (12-15%) due to hot climate, dehydration, and dietary factors. RTA is an under-recognized cause of recurrent stones. Many patients undergo repeated lithotripsy without addressing the underlying metabolic cause. Potassium citrate is affordable and available.

title: Lupus Nephritis in a Young Woman
chief_complaint: Facial rash, joint pains, and swelling of feet
presentation: A 22-year-old medical student from Delhi presents with a butterfly-shaped facial rash, polyarthralgia, bilateral pedal edema, and frothy urine for 2 months. She has had recurrent oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and hair loss. Her routine urine exam showed proteinuria and active sediment.
history: Butterfly rash on face for 3 months, worsens with sun exposure. Bilateral small joint pains (MCPs, PIPs, wrists) for 4 months, no deformity. Oral ulcers recurrent. Hair loss (diffuse). Photosensitivity. Bilateral pedal edema for 2 months. Frothy urine. Fatigue, malaise. No seizures. No pleuritic chest pain. LMP: Regular. Family history: Maternal aunt has 'lupus'.
physical_exam: Malar (butterfly) rash sparing nasolabial folds. Diffuse non-scarring alopecia. Oral ulcers on hard palate. Tender MCPs and PIPs bilaterally (non-erosive arthritis). Bilateral pedal edema. No pleural effusion. No lymphadenopathy. No hepatosplenomegaly.
investigations: ANA: Positive (1:640, homogeneous pattern). Anti-dsDNA: Strongly positive (450 IU/mL). C3: 40 mg/dL (low). C4: 5 mg/dL (very low). Anti-Smith: Positive. Urine: Protein 3+, RBCs 2+, RBC casts. 24-hour urine protein: 3.8g. Creatinine: 1.4. Albumin: 2.5. CBC: Hb 9.0 (hemolytic anemia, Coombs positive), WBC 3,000 (leucopenia), Platelets 100,000. ESR: 85 (elevated). CRP: 15 (less elevated than ESR — typical of SLE). Renal biopsy: Class IV diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis (ISN/RPS), Activity Index 12, Chronicity Index 3.
diagnosis: Systemic lupus erythematosus with Class IV diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis
learning_points: Lupus nephritis occurs in 50-70% of SLE patients — Class IV is most common and most serious
ISN/RPS Classification: I (minimal mesangial), II (mesangial proliferative), III (focal), IV (diffuse), V (membranous), VI (sclerosing)
Anti-dsDNA and low C3/C4 correlate with disease activity in lupus nephritis
Treatment Class III/IV: Induction with mycophenolate (MMF) or cyclophosphamide + steroids, then maintenance with MMF + low-dose pred
Voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor) added to MMF improves renal response — new addition
Belimumab (anti-BLyS) approved as add-on for active lupus nephritis
india_context: SLE prevalence in India is estimated at 30-50 per 100,000. Young women (15-40) are predominantly affected. Lupus nephritis is the most serious organ manifestation. Indian Rheumatology Association (IRA) guidelines recommend early biopsy. MMF is first-line induction in India (preferred over cyclophosphamide for fertility preservation). Generic MMF is affordable.

title: Obstructive Uropathy with AKI — Bilateral Ureteric Calculi
chief_complaint: No urine output for 24 hours with bilateral flank pain
presentation: A 45-year-old government clerk presents with anuria (no urine output) for 24 hours, bilateral severe flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. He has a known history of recurrent kidney stones and has passed multiple stones in the past. He presents with AKI and hyperkalemia.
history: Bilateral severe flank pain starting 2 days ago, initially left side, then right. Complete anuria for 24 hours. Nausea and vomiting. Known recurrent calcium oxalate stones for 10 years, has passed 6 stones. High dietary oxalate (spinach, tomato, chikoo). Low water intake. No prior surgical intervention. Family history of stones (father, uncle). Works in air-conditioned office, sedentary.
physical_exam: Distressed with pain. Bilateral renal angle tenderness. Suprapubic: Bladder not palpable (not urinary retention). No pedal edema. Mild periorbital puffiness.
investigations: Creatinine: 8.5 (baseline 1.0 — severe AKI). BUN: 90. K+: 6.8 (dangerous hyperkalemia). Na+: 132. Bicarbonate: 12 (metabolic acidosis). ECG: Peaked T waves, widened QRS (hyperkalemic changes). CT KUB (non-contrast): Right ureteric calculus 12mm at VUJ with proximal hydroureter and hydronephrosis. Left ureteric calculus 10mm at PUJ with severe hydronephrosis. Both kidneys: Dilated collecting systems. Renal USG: Bilateral moderate-severe hydronephrosis. CBC: Normal. Uric acid: 9.5.
diagnosis: Bilateral obstructive uropathy (bilateral ureteric calculi) causing postrenal acute kidney injury with life-threatening hyperkalemia
learning_points: Anuria = think obstruction first (bilateral or obstruction of single functioning kidney)
Postrenal AKI: Requires bilateral obstruction (or unilateral in single kidney) — most reversible cause of AKI
Emergency management: Treat hyperkalemia FIRST (IV calcium gluconate → insulin-dextrose → salbutamol), THEN relieve obstruction
Urgent decompression: Bilateral percutaneous nephrostomy or ureteric stenting (DJ stent)
Post-obstructive diuresis: After relief, expect massive polyuria (5-10 L/day) — replace fluids carefully
Stone prevention: >2.5L water daily, dietary oxalate restriction, potassium citrate, thiazide diuretics for hypercalciuria
india_context: India lies in the 'stone belt' — North India (Rajasthan, UP, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Punjab) has 12% prevalence. Hot climate, low water intake, and high oxalate diet (spinach, tomato) drive stone formation. DJ stenting and PCNL are available at district hospitals. ESWL availability is more limited.

title: CKD Stage 5 — Preparation for Dialysis
chief_complaint: Nausea, fatigue, and itching with very low kidney function
presentation: A 58-year-old retired teacher with long-standing hypertension presents with progressive fatigue, nausea, anorexia, generalized itching, and sleep disturbance for 2 months. His creatinine has gradually risen over 5 years from 2.0 to 7.5 mg/dL. He has been non-compliant with medications and follow-up. He now has uremic symptoms requiring dialysis initiation.
history: Known hypertension for 20 years, on amlodipine only (RAAS blocker stopped due to hyperkalemia 2 years ago). Progressive CKD: creatinine 2.0 (5 years ago) → 4.0 (2 years ago) → 7.5 (now). Not on ESA or phosphate binders. Uremic symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, anorexia for 2 months. Generalized pruritus (uremic itch). Restless legs at night. Fatigue, dyspnea on exertion. Weight loss 5 kg. No AV fistula created. No hepatitis B vaccination.
physical_exam: Pale, sallow complexion (uremic pallor). Scratch marks (pruritus). Uremic fetor. Pericardial friction rub (uremic pericarditis — indication for urgent dialysis). BP 175/105. Bilateral basal crepitations. Mild bilateral pedal edema. No AV fistula.
investigations: Creatinine: 7.5, eGFR: 7 mL/min (CKD Stage 5/ESRD). BUN: 110. K+: 6.0. Calcium: 7.5 (low). Phosphate: 7.8 (high). iPTH: 650 pg/mL (secondary hyperparathyroidism). Hb: 7.2 (renal anemia — EPO deficiency). Albumin: 2.8. Uric acid: 10.5. ABG: Metabolic acidosis (HCO3 14). Echo: LVH, pericardial effusion (uremic pericarditis). HBsAg/HCV: Negative. HBV antibody: Negative (not vaccinated). AV duplex: Veins suitable for fistula creation.
diagnosis: CKD Stage 5 (ESRD) due to hypertensive nephrosclerosis with uremic syndrome and uremic pericarditis — urgent dialysis indication
learning_points: Uremic pericarditis = absolute indication for urgent hemodialysis
Other urgent dialysis indications: Refractory hyperkalemia, refractory pulmonary edema, severe metabolic acidosis, uremic encephalopathy
CKD-MBD management: Phosphate binders (calcium acetate/sevelamer), calcitriol, cinacalcet for secondary hyperparathyroidism
Renal anemia: EPO-stimulating agents (epoetin/darbepoetin) when Hb <10, target 10-11.5
AV fistula should be created 6 months before anticipated dialysis start (maturation time)
HBV vaccination is essential for all CKD patients (double dose, 4-dose schedule)
india_context: India has an estimated 2 lakh ESRD patients, but only 10-15% can access dialysis. PM National Dialysis Programme (PMNDP) provides free hemodialysis at 550+ district hospitals. AV fistula creation is a skill gap in many centers. Peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) is an underutilized home-based alternative. Renal transplant is the best option but donor shortage is severe.
